trial_identification.studytitle: Chinese medical exercises for metabolic syndrome and diabetes control
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The efficacy of Tai Chi and Qigong in reducing indicators of risk of Type 2 diabetes in adults with elevated blood glucose - A randomized controlled trial

conditions.healthcondition: indicators of metabolic syndrome and diabetes control

interventions.interventions: Participantes in Group A attened Tai Chi/Qigong exercise group training classed 3 times a week for 12 weeks followed by 12 week self-led 'at home' training. Participants in Group B had no intervention during the first 12 weeks (waiting period); this was followed by Tai Chi/Qigong group training classes 3 times a week for the next 6 weeks, followed by self-led 'at home' training during the remaining 6 weeks
interventions.comparator: usual care (participants continued to receive usual care from their doctors during the 6 month study period).

primaryOutcome.outcome: Changes in indicators of metabolic syndrome including body mass index (BMI), waist circumference, blood pressure, fasting blood glucose, triglycerides and high density lipoprotein-cholesterol (HDL-C)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Physical measurement conducted at baseline (after randominzation), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, 18 weeks and 24 weeks; haematological measurement conducted at baseline (after randomization), 12 weeks and 24 weeks.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Changes in other indicators of diabetes control including HbA1c, fasting insulin, 2 hour blood glucose, 2 hour blood insulin, total cholesterol, low density lipoprotein-cholesterol (LDL-C); and derived estimates from the blood glucose and insulin, including insulin resistance, metabolic clearance rate and beta cell function
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at baseline (after randomization), 12 weeks and 24 weeks

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Changes in psychological measures including stress, depression, self-efficacy for physical activity, social support for physical activity
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at baseline (after randominzation), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, 18 weeks and 24 weeks

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Changes in indicators of strength, general health and well-being including leg strength, diabetic symptoms, quality of life
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at baseline (after randominzation), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, 18 weeks and 24 weeks

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Changes in behaviour measures including physical activity
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at baseline (after randominzation), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, 18 weeks and 24 weeks

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Elevated blood glucose (> 5.6 mmol/L) but not currently taking diabetes medication and not being on diabetes medication in the three months prior to the program.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Medical condition which contraindicates participation in physical activity as suggested by the American College of Sports Medicine 2000; unwilling or unable to attend three sessions/week for 6 or 12 consecutive weeks.

trial_design.concealment: After priliminary eligibility screening by telephone, potential participants were referred to GP for obtaining clearance to participate followed by randomization (prior to baseline assessment). Consent forms were obtained from all participants prior to baseline assessment. Central randomisation allocation was done by computer.
trial_design.sequence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated randomisation schedule by a research assisstant

fundingsource.fundingaddress: 5th Floor, 39 London Circuit Canberra City ACT 2600

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The primary purpose of the study was to determine the effects of a Tai Chi/Qigong intervention program on variables associated with metabolic syndrome and/or diabetes control, and on other psychological, general health, and physical activity variables.
